column1: The fierce hatred of England in Germany is due in large measure to what the Germans call "the shopkeepers' warfare" of the English. They maintain that the English confiscation of German patents is a wholly unfair method of fighting
column2: and it has caused the deepest resentment. When asked as to the future
column3: they reply that they will do all in due time. After Belgium will come France
column4: and then the turn of England will arrive. They are not discouraged by the failure to reach Paris
column5: since the strategy adopted by the French would have rendered the possession of Paris of little value. It will still be taken.With regard to England not much is said of an army of invasion
column6: but German confidence is evidently reposed in her Zeppelins
column7: of which a large number is being constructed with all possible speed. They are to be employed against England
column8: whose part in the war is the least honorable of all. Belgium's attitude at the outset they can understand
column9: France's desire for la revanche is natural
column10: but England's only motive was jealousy of Germany's industrial development and the desire to cripple her trade and commercial prosperity. Therefore
